conclusion: Analyze forces acting on block and plank to determine condition for F1.
Forces on the block include tension from plank, normal force, vertical force F2, horizontal force F1, and frictional force.
Vertical motion equation: F2 - mg = may, with ay not equal to 0.
Horizontal motion equation: F1 - f = max, with ax not equal to 0.
Maximum static friction force is fmax = μN, and f = μN when block is about to slide.
Normal force N is provided by vertical component of tension: N = T sin θ.
For horizontal equilibrium of plank: T cos θ = F1, thus T = F1/cos θ.
For vertical equilibrium of plank: T sin θ + F2 = Mg, leading to F1 tan θ + F2 = Mg.
Block will slide if F1 ≤ μN, substituting N = T sin θ gives F1 ≤ μT sin θ.
Substituting T gives F1 ≤ μ(F1/cos θ) sin θ, simplifying to 1 ≤ μ tan θ.
With μ = 0.20, condition becomes tan θ ≥ 5.
For upward acceleration: ay > 0, thus F2 ≥ mg.
Substituting F2 = Mg - F1 tan θ into F2 ≥ mg gives mg ≤ Mg - F1 tan θ.
Simplifying gives F1 tan θ ≤ M(g - g), leading to F1 tan θ ≤ 0.20.
